<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_irq_ack(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 int irq)
{
	(void)lbus;
	(void)irq;
	int irq_info = 1;
	unsigned int val;
	int ret;

	ret = read(ldev->fd, (void *)&val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, read uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, ret);
		return;
	}
	ret = write(ldev->fd, &irq_info, sizeof(irq_info));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, write uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, errno);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments modify any of the function parameters (lbus, ldev, irq), so none need investigation for Rule 17.8. Specific reasons:
- The casts (void)lbus; and (void)irq; only mark parameters as intentionally unused; they do not assign to or alter the parameters.
- There is no assignment to lbus, ldev, or irq anywhere (no statements like ldev = ..., lbus = ..., irq = ...), and no pointer arithmetic applied to the pointer parameters.
- Accesses such as ldev->fd read or use the object referred to by the pointer parameter; Rule 17.8 explicitly allows modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter, provided the pointer itself is not modified. In this code ldev is only dereferenced to obtain fd and not reassigned.
- The read call writes into the local variable val ((void *)&val), not into any parameter. The write call sends the address of the local irq_info variable; again this does not modify any parameter.
- No function is called with the address of a parameter (no &lbus or &ldev), so there is no indirect modification of the pointer parameters via pointer-to-pointer.
Given the above, there are no violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided function.
